The Garden of the Finzi-Continis is considered the best of the series of novels that Bassani produced about the lives of Italian Jews in the northern Italian city of Ferrara. Although the novel focuses on the relationships between the major characters, the shadow of creeping Italian fascism, especially the racial laws that restricted Jews' participation in Italian society, looms over all the novel's events. According to Bassani, one hundred and eighty-three Jews living in Ferrara were deported to German concentration camps, predominantly under the puppet Italian Social Republic in 1943."Introduction", p. x, Jamie McKendrick, Penguin edition, 2007

There are at least three English translations of the novel: the first by Isabel Quigly (1965, mentioned above), one by William Weaver (Quartet Books, 1974) and one by Jamie McKendrick (Penguin, 2007),
